security_audit.summary: This skill is a legitimate development automation tool for Claude Code hooks. The static analyzer detected 189 potential issues, but investigation reveals these are primarily false positives. The backtick executions are documentation examples showing CLI usage patterns, not executable code. The skill provides workflow automation through shell command hooks that users configure. Minor risk from external command execution is acceptable given the intended use case.

low_findings.title: Documentation Contains Shell Command Examples
low_findings.description: The skill documentation extensively demonstrates CLI usage with backtick code examples. These are legitimate documentation patterns showing users how to invoke the claude-flow hook commands. Not executable code, but documentation examples that static analysis flagged.

low_findings.title: Filesystem Operations in Hook Commands
low_findings.description: The skill enables hooks that perform filesystem operations like file validation, backup creation, and temp file cleanup. These are legitimate operations for development workflow automation tools. Users configure and control these operations through their .claude/settings.json configuration.

content.user_title: Automate Development Workflows with Intelligent Hooks
content.value_statement: Managing Claude Code operations manually is time-consuming and error-prone. This skill provides intelligent hooks that automatically coordinate agents, format code, validate syntax, and learn from patterns to streamline your development workflow.
actual_capabilities: Execute pre-operation hooks before file edits, bash commands, and tasks to validate and prepare
Run post-operation hooks after operations to auto-format code, store decisions in memory, and train patterns
Manage session lifecycle with automatic state persistence, context restoration, and metrics export
Coordinate memory across swarm agents using standardized three-phase protocol
Integrate with Git operations through pre-commit, post-commit, and pre-push hooks
Automatically spawn and assign agents based on task complexity and file types
limitations: Requires Claude Flow CLI installation and proper configuration in .claude/settings.json
Hook execution adds latency to operations (target under 100ms per hook)
MCP server integration requires separate setup for full coordination features
Custom hook development requires JavaScript knowledge and understanding of hook lifecycle

best_practices: Configure hooks during project initialization and test them with debug mode enabled before production use
Use memory keys with clear namespaces like swarm/agent-type/context-name for organized coordination
Set appropriate timeouts for hooks (target under 100ms, use async for heavy operations) to avoid blocking workflows
anti_patterns: Avoid creating synchronous hooks that perform slow operations like network requests or full test suite runs
Do not skip hook validation and testing before enabling in production environments
Never hardcode sensitive credentials or API keys in hook command configurations

faq.question: Do I need MCP servers to use this skill?
faq.answer: MCP servers are optional. Basic hooks work without MCP. For advanced features like agent coordination, memory sync, and neural training, you need claude-flow MCP server installed.

faq.question: How do hooks affect Claude Code performance?
faq.answer: Each hook adds execution time to operations. Target under 100ms per hook. Use async mode for heavy operations. Monitor with debug mode and optimize hooks that exceed timeout thresholds.

faq.question: Can I disable specific hooks temporarily?
faq.answer: Yes. Edit .claude/settings.json and remove or comment out specific hook configurations. You can also set continueOnError to true to allow operations even if hooks fail.

faq.question: How do I debug hooks that are not working?
faq.answer: Enable debug mode with export CLAUDE_FLOW_DEBUG=true, check .claude-flow/logs for execution logs, validate configuration with npx claude-flow hook validate-config, and test hooks individually with the --debug flag.

faq.question: Can hooks access environment variables?
faq.answer: Yes. Hook commands run in your shell environment and can access environment variables. Be careful not to expose sensitive credentials in hook configurations or logs.

faq.question: How do multiple agents coordinate through hooks?
faq.answer: Hooks use a three-phase memory protocol (status, progress, complete) to store state in MCP memory. Agents read and write to shared memory namespaces like swarm/agent-type/context to coordinate work and share decisions.
